title: Nancy Pelosi says she will NOT hold an immediate House vote on impeachment
text:
Nancy Pelosi has said no to a full House vote on the impeachment inquiry into Donald Trump - at least for now, sparing vulnerable lawmakers from having to take a a public position on a politically tough issue.

'There's no requirement we have a vote and at this time we'll not be having one,' she said on Capitol Hill Tuesday night.

The president and Republican lawmakers have blasted the speaker for not holding such a vote, which she has long argued is not necessary for Democrats to proceed.

But she is ignoring their demand.

'We're not here to call bluffs. We're here to find the truth,' Pelosi said in response to the pressure from Republicans and the White House.

Speaker Nancy Pelosi has said no to a full House vote on the impeachment inquiry into Trump

President Trump and Republicans have argued the impeachment inquiry isn't legitimate without a vote

She charged Republicans have turned to attacking the process as they have no substance to defend the president.

'They have no substance. They can't defend the president so they're going to process,' she said after a press conference on Capitol Hill after a meeting with her Democratic lawmakers.

There are reports of disagreement among Pelosi and her leadership team - including the committee chairs leading the investigation into Trump - about whether or not to hold such a vote.

Pelosi can still call one at a future date.

A vote would undermine a key Republican argument that questions the legitimacy of the inquiry but it would also put vulnerable Democratic members in swing House districts in a tough spot ahead of next year's election.

Pelosi and the Democratic leadership team have been taking the temperature of the caucus to see if there is an appetite for such a vote.

Given that one is not happening, it is likely they are getting push back from lawmakers worried about the 2020 election.

Democrats hold the majority in the House and such a vote would pass but it is the political implications the speaker is wary of.

And even some Republican lawmakers would be uneasy about being put in the politically tough spot of having to go on the record.

White House Counsel Pat Cipollone wrote to Pelosi last week the process was 'illegitimate' and 'constitutionally invalid' without a full House vote.

'In the history of our nation, the House of Representatives has never attempted to launch an impeachment inquiry against the president without a majority of the House taking political accountability for that decision by voting to authorize such a dramatic constitutional step,' he argued.
description: Nancy Pelosi has said no to a full House vote on the impeachment inquiry into Donald Trump - at least for now, sparing vulnerable lawmakers from having to take  a a public position on a politically tough issue.
